page.title: 19YALDING'S NATURAL HISTORY
page.content: Indigenous trees are predominantly oak, ash, also hedgerow elms which die at about 6 metres tall, presumably from Dutch elm disease. By the river- side are alder and willow. Soil greedy poplars used for windbreaks are being replaced by soil enriching alders. Hedgerows, some believed very old, include hawthorn, field maple and hazel. Typical woodland flora includes abundant bluebells with celandines, yellow archangel, wood anemones, primroses and wild violets. Greybury Wood, of coppiced chestnut, is a mass of bluebells in May. Low lying ground has meadowsweet, purple loosestrife, Himalayan balsam, yellow flag irises, kingcups and reeds. Fauna is diverse with many rabbits and foxes, some badgers and mink and a good spread of resident birds.
